description: Individuals eligible and enrolled simultaneously for Medicare and Medicaid commonly referred to as dual eligible or duals have often been cited as accounting for a disproportionate share of Medicare and Medicaid spending compared with non-dual eligible beneficiaries. In the Medicare program, dual eligible beneficiaries account for 16 percent of enrollees, but about 25 percent of expenditures. In Medicaid, they account for 18 percent of enrollees, but about 46 percent of expenditures. Despite important policy implications presented by duals, published information on this population is sparse.
title: Effect of Long-term Care Use on Medicare and Medicaid...
